This report was prepared by Tatiana Gallego-Lizon and Raza M. Farrukh, South Asia Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2002, the Government of Pakistan requested technical assistance (TA) to prepare a 
project to provide basic urban services to poor communities in the Province of Sindh. The Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Country Strategy and Program Update for the Islamic Republic of 
Pakistan includes the provision for such TA, proposed for ADB financing in 2004. The ADB 
Fact-Finding Mission visited Pakistan during 11–19 October 2004, formulated the TA in line with 
the program of actions formalized in the poverty reduction partnership agreement between the 
Government and ADB, and reached preliminary understanding with the Government on the 
goals, purpose, scope, implementation and financing arrangements, cost and terms of reference 
of the TA.1 A preliminary project framework for the ensuing Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Pakistan  ranks  142nd  out  of  175  countries  on  the  United  Nations  Development 
Programme human development index (2004). The annual population growth rate of Sindh2 
(1981–98) was 2.8% against the national average of 2.1%. As in most of Pakistan, Sindh’s most 
pressing needs over the next quarter century include managing a rapidly increasing population, 
and the provision of basic amenities: food, domestic water supply,3 waste management, and 
power.4 Half of Sindh’s population lives in urban areas, where one third of the population is 
poor,5 living on less than a dollar a day. The initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
3.  Urban areas in Sindh are growing rapidly, at a rate of about 3.5% or over 1.4 million per 
annum. Although efforts to stimulate rural development can reduce the rate of in-migration to 
urban areas, 65–75% of Pakistan’s urban growth rate is due to natural population increase. 
Urban growth is likely to continue regardless of actions taken in rural areas. Thus, failure to 
invest in urban areas will result in deteriorating living conditions, particularly for the poor. At 
least 40% of the increasing urban population is accommodated in unauthorized or informal 
settlements.6 These are rarely supplied with infrastructure and social services when they are 
first inhabited. Unauthorized settlements on publicly owned land, or katchi abadis,7 predominate 
in Sindh, over unregulated subdivisions of privately owned land, which are a more common form 
of informal development in other provinces.  
 
4.  The Government has accepted the need to provide services to informal areas, however, 
limited financial, institutional, and human resources; the lack of priority given to the needs of 
informal areas; the tendency to work in piecemeal manner; and difficulties with operation and 
maintenance have resulted in inadequate services to informal areas. Levels of urban services 
within the province are low and services in most settlements continue to be far from adequate. 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 20 January 2004.  
2  Sindh is one of Pakistan’s four administrative provinces covering 140,900 square kilometers (17.7% of the total 
area) divided into 16 districts and has a population of 32.3 million (22.9% of the country’s population). 
3  More than two thirds of Sindh is in the brackish water or desert zone, while only 17% is in the freshwater zone. 
4  A significant and sustained effort will be required for social sector development in Sindh, considering that infant 
mortality rate is 83 per 1,000 live births, and life expectancy is estimated at 63 years for men and women. 
5  ADB. 2001. Poverty Assessment Report. Manila, estimates poverty incidence in urban areas in Sindh to be 35.2%.  
6  The rate of growth of katchi abadis is estimated to be approximately 10% per annum. D. Dowall. 1989. Karachi 
Land and Housing Study, KDA-MPD. 
7  Regularization of katchi abadis involved government recognition of a katchi abadis’ right to exist and the need to 
provide residents with de-facto security of tenure. They can obtain long-term leases on their land in return for 
payment to government based on the size of plot and the appropriate rate of payment for the size of the plot. 
Although Government regularized most katchi abadis containing more than 40 houses in 1985, no further 
regularization has taken place since then.

2  
The percentage of urban dwellers in Sindh with piped water on plot increased from 68% in 1990 
to  an  estimated  80%  in  2001.  Despite  significant  efforts  to  provide  a  continued  gradual 
improvement in the percentage of people with water connections, figures show that, because of 
population increase, the total number of people without adequate water supply is increasing. 
Total uncovered population projections indicate that water supply shortages will affect 11 million 
people living in urban areas in 2014, while more than 9 million people will not have drainage 
systems in the same year.8 Moreover, even where a distribution system is present, the limited 
period of supply and low water pressure increase the likelihood of cross-contamination from 
nearby sewers, endangering water quality. Levels of urban services within the urban centers of 
the province are low, with coverage and service levels varying greatly between talukas. While 
most of the medium-size towns have a water supply system, only 35–45% of households are 
connected.  
 
5.  In many informal areas, pour-flush systems are rapidly replacing crude dry toilets. 
Sewerage  and  drainage  is  more  problematic.9 Most informal areas are not sewered, and 
existing sewers are often in poor condition, badly silted, and need frequent maintenance. Very 
few sewers discharge to adequate treatment facilities.10 Where official sewers are not present, 
most households discharge sewage to open drains, either directly or through septic tanks. 
Storm-water drainage facilities in cities are generally poor; the nullahs receive little cleaning and 
maintenance. This situation is made worse in informal areas, due to lack of overall settlement 
planning,  poor  maintenance,  and  encroachment  on  drainage  channels.  Many  informal 
settlements located in poorly drained low-lying land can be subject to flooding resulting in ponds 
of stagnant water providing breeding grounds for mosquitoes and waterborne diseases.  
 
6.  Formal solid waste management services in Pakistan and in Sindh deal with less than 
50% of solid waste produced, affecting worst the informal settlements.11 Waste material is 
burned, dumped in open spaces, used for uncontrolled landfill and land reclamation, or thrown 
into drains and watercourses. Waste is also collected by scavengers or transferred to potter’s 
settlements to be used as fuel in kilns. Informal recycling systems12 cover certain types of waste 
and suffer from high inefficiencies, while hazardous pollutants are disposed of in a random and 
unsafe manner. Uncollected waste represents a serious hazard to both public health and the 
environment. Little data is available on the overall percentage of paved streets and lanes in 
informal areas, but these are generally narrow and poorly maintained and usually characterized 
by poor standards of construction. Lack of paving restricts access and circulation, adversely 
affecting the operation of services such as solid waste collection, and tending to increase the 
duration and impact of flooding.   
 
7.  Under the Sindh Local Government Ordinance, 2001, tehsil municipal authorities (TMAs) 
headed by the taluka/town nazims are responsible for planning, investment, and control of 
municipal services, including water supply, sanitation, and solid waste disposal. Karachi City

Public Health Engineering Department. 
9  While sanitation services provided to planned areas in Karachi are estimated at 85%, services to Katchi Abadis are 
reported to cover only 12% of the population, Tabulation of AERC Survey, 1989. 
10  Sewage treatment is generally absent throughout Sindh, with the exception of Karachi, where only an estimated 
50% of the city’s municipal sewage is treated. Areas serviced often do not cover poorer informal settlements. 
11  Solid waste generated in Pakistan ranges between 0.283 and 0.612 kilograms per capita per day, with a reported 
growth rate of 2.4% per year. Solid waste management services provided to katchi abadis were reported to cover 
approximately 10% of the total area, Tabulation of AERC Survey, 1989.  
12 These include large-scale waste dealers (1,000 kabaris are reported to operate in Karachi), and original initiatives 
by nongovernment organizations such as Gul Bahao through its  Safai Kamai garbage purchasing bank, the 
Pakistan Environment Recycling Program, and Sheri’s solid waste management public awareness activities.

3
District has 18 TMAs, while the remaining 15 districts of the province in aggregate, have 84. 
Since devolution, the Public Health Engineering Department merged with the Local Government 
Department (LGD) and responsibilities for planning and operating schemes were devolved to 
the TMAs. Partly due to the inherent problems related to lack of funds and capacity to execute 
these new responsibilities, the TMAs have not properly assumed the responsibilities envisaged 
under the 2001 ordinance. TMA capacity building, addressed under the Sindh Devolved Social 
Services Program, needs to be continued under other initiatives. Katchi abadi departments were 
set  up  in  Punjab  and  Sindh  in  the  mid  1980s  to  manage  the  process  of  katchi  abadi 
regularization and to channel funds to upgrade schemes in informal areas. The Sindh Katchi 
Abadi Authority, merged with LGD after devolution, is undertaking innovative and constructive 
work. 
 
8.  Lessons learned from previous ADBs projects in the sector in Sindh and Pakistan 
indicate that (i) urban upgrading should be designed from a plan that integrates all aspects of 
urban  infrastructure  and  involves  the  participation  of  beneficiaries  in  project  design, 
implementation,  operation,  and  maintenance;  successful  experiences  have  also  shown 
beneficiaries commitment through component cost-sharing,13 (ii) institutional capacity must be 
developed, (iii) the financial framework must be in place to ensure long-term sustainability, and 
(iv) awareness raising for sanitation and the environment must be undertaken. The TA supports 
Pakistan’s Ten-Year Perspective Development Plan (2001–2011).14 The TA is consistent with 
ADB’s Country Strategy and Program (2002–2006), which emphasizes support for governance 
reform programs and devolution, provision of basic urban services and water, inclusive social 
development, and sustainable environmental management.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The  goal  of  the  TA  is  to  facilitate  sustainable  urban  development  for  low-income 
communities in Sindh. Its objective is to assist the Government in preparing a project to improve 
basic  urban  infrastructure  and  services  in  a  participatory  manner  in  selected  low-income 
communities  in  urban  centers  in  Sindh.  The  TA’s  output  will  consist  of  (i)  a  sector  and 
institutional  analysis  review  and  data  collection  study,  (ii)  a  participatory  framework  for 
community participation leading to the formulation of priority infrastructure and institutional 
arrangements, and (iii) a feasibility study suitable for ADB financing.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  In  keeping  with  the  Government’s  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  Paper,  the  TA  will 
emphasize targeting assistance to the poorest urban areas in Sindh with the most acute 
shortages of drinking water, sanitation, and solid waste management, while supporting inclusive 
social development and devolution of authority, strengthening of local government, and seeking 
opportunities to promote women’s participation. The TA will aim to increase transparency, 
complementing  activities  undertaken  locally  or  by  other  assisting  agencies,  and  involving 
stakeholders from early stages of the planning and design process. The TA will be implemented 
in an inclusive manner, ensuring that the design of the ensuing Project has not only an 
                                                 
13  Cost-sharing and component-sharing initiatives, such as those undertaken in Orangi, have resulted in commitment 
and ownership development among communities, awareness raising, and community empowerment. Proposed 
cost-sharing arrangements for the Project should be consistent with the Government’s cost-sharing policies. 
14 Pakistan’s Ten-Year Perspective Development Plan (2001–2011) includes the provision of safe drinking water from 
the current 63% (83% urban and 53% rural) to 84% (96% urban and 75% rural) of the population by 2011.

4  
integrated approach but also draws all actors and stakeholders into the upgrading process in a 
way that validates and strengthens them.  
 
11.  The TA will be carried out in three phases over 8 months. Phase I will (i) collect and 
review basic planning data and processes, capabilities, and resources for urban development in 
secondary urban centers, with particular emphasis in more deprived areas; (ii) conduct a 
socioeconomic assessment in the identified target areas; (iii) geographically map and analyze 
poverty data, incidence of waterborne diseases, current and projected assistance, concentration 
of  minority  and  disadvantaged  groups,  and  the  distribution  and  capabilities  of  local 
nongovernment  organizations;  (iv)  undertake  engineering  field  surveys  and  mapping  to 
ascertain the condition of basic infrastructure and amenities, including current data on water and 
sanitation and solid waste management coverage; (v) identify priority areas15 based on need for 
improved coverage; (vi) analyze the policy and institutional setup; and (vii) assess existing 
financial arrangements. 
 
12.  Phase II will integrate findings from the phase I analysis with local knowledge through a 
professionally  facilitated  participatory  process.  Phase  II  will  develop  the  project  framework 
through consensus with the various stakeholders to jointly identify and prioritize needs, options, 
and priorities of various groups of the urban population, especially the poorest sectors. The TA 
will be informed by the water supply and sanitation and solid waste management policies, 
strategies, and plans developed under the Capacity Building for Environmental Management in 
Sindh TA.16 
 
13.  Phase  III  will  select  and  refine  project  subsector-specific  investment  components; 
develop technical options acceptable to all stakeholders; and conduct economic and financial 
feasibility studies, environmental and social studies, and other documentation as required by 
ADB guidelines. An institutional development and capacity-building program will support the 
prioritized infrastructure development project in selected cities.  In addition to  infrastructure 
upgrading, foreseen to include improvements to water supply, sanitation, sewage treatment, 
solid waste management, drainage, access roads, and footpaths, subcomponents such as 
health and hygiene education will be considered. The TA team will coordinate with the Devolved 
Social Services Program coordination unit to optimize component selection, coverage, and 
sequencing, and prevent duplication in the allocation of funds.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $995,000 equivalent, comprising $475,000 in 
foreign exchange costs and $520,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance 
$795,000 equivalent, which will cover the entire foreign exchange cost, and $320,000 equivalent 
of the local currency costs. The remaining $200,000 equivalent will be contributed by the 
Government  and  will  include  office  accommodation,  transportation,  counterpart  staff, 
background reports, studies and logistics, and workshop facilities. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are provided in Appendix 3. The Government has been advised 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
                                                 
15  Provision, improvement, and rehabilitation of basic urban services in Karachi and Hyderabad are to be included in 
the proposed Megacity Project I, for which project preparation is expected to take place in 2005. 
16  ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for Capacity Building for Environmental 
Management in Sindh. Manila.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  LGD,  the  Executing  Agency,  will  appoint  a  TA  unit  coordinator  with  a  supportive, 
coordinating,  and  facilitating  role;  and  provide  office  space,  furniture,  equipment,  and 
professional  and  support  counterpart  staff  for  the  TA  consultants  as  necessary.  Overall 
guidance for TA implementation will be provided by a TA steering committee, headed by the 
additional chief secretary, Planning and Development Department, comprising senior officials 
from provincial government agencies, including LGD, Planning and Development Department, 
Finance Department, and  Sindh  Environmental  Protection  Agency; district government and 
TMAs; aid agencies; nongovernment organizations; and private sector groups active in the 
sector. The steering committee will first meet no later than 5 weeks after the start of the TA to 
finalize  the  appropriate  coverage  area  selection,  and  then  on  a  quarterly  basis  or  more 
frequently if required, to review TA progress and provide direction, particularly on policy issues.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 8 months from May 2005 to December 2005. A team of 
international and domestic consultants will be selected and recruited through a firm by ADB to 
provide a total of 63 person-months of consulting services comprising 21 person-months of 
international consulting and 42 person-months of domestic consulting, which includes 8 person-
months of unallocated consulting services. The consultants will be selected and engaged by 
ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank 
and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. The outline terms of reference for TA consultants and indicative scheduling are 
presented in Appendix 4. The international consultants will include experts in water supply and 
sanitation, economics, solid waste management, urban governance, policy and institutions, and 
environment.  The  domestic  consultants  will  include  experts  in  social  development  and 
community  mobilization,  gender  and  resettlement,  groundwater  and  hydrology,  financial 
analysis, sewerage, drainage, and environment. ADB’s full technical proposal approach will be 
used in selecting consultants. Workshops will take place in all three phases of the TA, but 
extended consultations (2–3 days per urban center) will be held for consensus building during 
phase II. Office equipment to be financed by the TA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
17.  The consultants will submit four major reports: (i) an inception report no later than 4 
weeks after commencement of services; (ii) a midterm report no later than the end of the fourth 
month; (iii) a draft final report at the end of the seventh month and (iv) a final report within 4 
weeks of receiving comments from the Government and ADB on the draft final report. In 
addition, the consultants will submit short monthly progress notes summarizing project activities, 
issues, constraints, and proposed solutions. Tripartite meetings will be held with ADB, the 
Government, and the consultants to review the inception, midterm, and draft final reports and 
verify output-to-purpose accomplishments. Key deliverables from this TA will be translated by 
consultants to facilitate their review by Government and other stakeholders. LGD will complete a 
TA completion questionnaire to evaluate the TA’s inputs and outputs, identify lessons learned, 
and suggest follow-up actions.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $795,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the Sindh Basic Urban Services Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
Pakistan faces the twin challenges of reviving economic growth and reducing poverty. The incidence of poverty in 
Pakistan has risen slowly but steadily during the 1990s, from 29.3% in 1993–1994 to 32.2% in 1998–1999. Poverty in 
urban areas is estimated to be 22.4%. Only 63% of the country’s population has access to safe drinking water (83% in 
urban areas, and 53% in rural areas). Proper sanitation facilities are available to only 39% of the population (59% in 
urban areas, and 27% in rural areas). Poor access to water supply and sanitation is often associated with poor health. 
Consolidated (federal and provincial) expenditures on water supply and sanitation have actually decreased over the 
past 5 years, both in nominal terms and as a percentage of gross domestic product. As a result, extension of public 
water supply and sanitation facilities has not kept pace with the growing needs of the rising population. Poverty 
incidence in urban areas in Sindh affects one third of the population, suffering from a lack of employment, low 
household incomes, and lack of basic services. 
 
The Poverty Partnership Agreement between the Government of Pakistan and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
reflects the Government’s vision for poverty reduction and key priorities of ADB’s Country Strategy and Program. 
ADB’s country strategy for Pakistan emphasizes water supply, sanitation and urban development, and the need to 
target the poor to reduce both poverty and inequalities. The Government, in its Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, 
builds on the notion that poverty reduction requires good governance; allocation for social sectors; and improving 
basic social services, including water supply and sanitation to enhance human development. The Poverty Partnership 
Agreement also focuses on attainment of the Millennium Development Goals, of which provision of drinking water is of 
great relevance. Access to safe drinking water, improved sanitation, and improved environmental quality will reduce 
vulnerability to environmental hazards for the poor communities. Improved quantity and quality of domestic water 
supply and sanitation facilities will reduce morbidity and mortality, especially for young children. The availability of safe 
drinking water supplies will reduce water-carrying time, which will benefit mainly women and girls.  
 
 
B.  Targeting Classification: Targeted Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?   
 
A multidimensional poverty analysis will be required for the Project. Although a good starting source, national and 
provincial survey data does not contain detail data at the local level. Data at taluka level on population, illiteracy, water 
and electricity availability, and other human development indexes will be utilized as part of the coverage selection 
criteria, however this will be refined, as talukas under the devolution process cover both urban and rural areas. A 
detailed socioeconomic survey will be conducted for selected urban centers and data collected will include income and 
expenditure, demographic trends, gender issues, health, water and sanitation, child labor, and urban environment. 
The findings of the socioeconomic baseline survey will be used to improve the access of the poor to existing and 
newly created infrastructure facilities and urban services. Participatory methods and innovative techniques in poverty 
assessment, such as the Alleppey method, will be considered, for identifying most disadvantaged and vulnerable 
groups. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Stakeholders to participate in the Project include the urban poor, including women; minorities from various nonlocal 
tribes or other religious groups; all tiers of government, especially taluka, district governments, and various provincial 
government  departments  (Local  Government  Department,  Planning  and  Development  Department,  Finance 
Department, Department of Health, Sindh Environmental Protection Agency); aid agencies such as United Nations 
Children’s Fund, nongovernment organizations; and, where relevant and appropriate, selected members of the private 
sector).

8  Appendix 2 
 
 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
The participation strategy for the technical assistance (TA) will focus on putting the urban poor at the center of 
development, through planning and design of the Project, and at a later stage, at the center of implementation, 
management, and operation and maintenance. The Project will involve the communities from phase I by conducting a 
socioeconomic analysis to include appreciative enquiry and rapid assessment methods, as well as community 
participation in the identification and mapping of current urban infrastructure and services. Phase II will put the 
communities and town at the center of the design process, which will be carried through to phase III of the Project. 
Workshops will be carried out with representatives of all stakeholder groups during all three project phases. The 
participatory project mechanism will be built on the self-help tradition while honoring local culture. The existing 
structure of extended households provide natural groupings that can be mobilized, strengthened, and utilized as a 
nucleus for community-based organizations with whom partnership will be built and to whose demands the Project 
could respond. The citizen community boards can be an excellent entry point to discuss and establish development 
oriented community participation. This will provide for grassroots participatory development. This approach ensures (i) 
full participation of beneficiaries in project design and implementation leading to greater ownership; (ii) a process 
approach; (iii) decentralized and localized implementation arrangements with capacity support to government and 
community groups in implementation and maintenance; and (iv) use of more widely accepted technology. 
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women:  
 
An important finding of the Participatory Poverty Assessment carried out for the Pakistan Poverty Reduction Strategy 
Paper showed that women are among the poorest and most vulnerable groups in the country. Women are primary 
collectors, transporters, users, and managers of domestic water and promoters of home and community-based 
sanitation activities. Yet, in Pakistan, women’s views are not systematically represented in decision-making bodies. 
Better access to water will give women more time for income-generating activities, their welfare, or the needs of family 
members; and it empowers them. It will also free children from the drudgery of water collection and management, 
especially girls who can then go to school. The Project will specifically address gender issues including participation of 
women in planning and design, and identification of constraints and opportunities for women to actively contribute to 
the implementation of the ensuing Project. A gender action plan for the Project will be prepared. Targeting of women 
requires a modified approach consistent with local culture and traditions in different parts of Pakistan. To create and 
develop acceptance for women’s activities, women organizers may visit selected urban centers to identify interested 
leading women and women organizations may be formed. To facilitate this process, social mobilizers can be recruited 
from among the most outspoken and conservative community members after their participation in a training workshop 
on rights, responsibilities, development process, and empowerment under traditional and customary practices. In 
addition, facilitation may be carried out through specialized nongovernment organizations and women counselors.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented over 8 months in 3 phases, some of 
the phases may partially overlap, as needed by the feasibility study.  
 
A.  Sectoral Review, Institutional Analysis, and Data Collection Study (2 months) 
2.  Shortfalls, Constraints, and Lessons Learned. Review and analyze previous national 
and provincial studies, reports, urban data, and related information including lessons learned 
from past water supply and sanitation, solid waste management, and urban development 
projects in Pakistan. Review the experience of projects assisted by ADB and other agencies, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations, and local initiatives in 
urban development, especially those involving low-income community upgrading. Share lessons 
learned with provincial and district governments and town officials, as well as representatives of 
citizen groups. Include findings and reflect responses in inception report. 
 
3.  City Selection. The consultants will review existing poverty per capita data, access to 
basic services by the poor, and acuteness of environmental problems in preselected urban 
centers1  in  Sindh.  Based  on  this  and  other  relevant  data,  the  consultants  will  develop 
appropriate  methodology  and  criteria,  and  finalize  the  selection  of  4- 5 urban centers in 
consultation with stakeholders, identify the list of areas for inclusion in the Project, and present it 
to the TA steering committee for discussion and endorsement. 
 
4.  Poverty Assessment. Review the Government’s National Poverty Strategy Program. 
Guided by ADB’s  Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis. The consultants will conduct a 
detailed poverty and social analysis for selected urban areas. Specific activities will include but 
not be limited to (i) conduct a full socioeconomic survey2 of project beneficiaries by gender and 
income group, estimate the number of project beneficiaries with income below the official 
poverty line, conduct an affordability analysis, and identify vulnerable groups (including any 
potential  minorities);  (ii)  conduct  a  gender  analysis,  and  identify  potential  constraints  and 
opportunities  for  women’s  participation  in  project  design,  implementation,  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) and training; (iii) evaluate social and economic benefits, and assess project 
impacts, recommending mitigation measures; (iv) collect and analyze health data, including 
morbidity and mortality rates dues to waterborne diseases; (v) analyze and evaluate slum social 
networks; (vi) prepare an overall framework for groups participation in project preparation, 
implementation, and postproject completion activities.   
 
5.  Policy  and  Institutional  Framework.  The  consultants  will  (i)  review  the  status  of 
implementation of Local Government Ordinance, 2001, and its impact on tehsils and districts; 
current level of responsibility and accountability, and existing funding mechanisms for urban 
infrastructure at national, provincial, and local levels; (ii) review provincial and district/local 
institutional arrangements, assess the defined roles of each level of government, and the roles 
played by community-based organizations, women’s groups, NGOs, and private sector in the 
delivery  of  basic  urban  services  and  programs  with  a  poverty  focus;  (iii)  analyze  the 
district/tehsil government administration structure, including staffing capacities and capabilities, 
budgets, finance resource base, cost recovery mechanism for urban infrastructure and services, 
revenue collection performance, accounting, internal control mechanisms, and procurement 
procedures, (iv) assess and evaluate NGOs presence and potential role in Project areas. 
                                                 
1  A list of 8–10 priority urban centers will be provided by the government of Sindh through LGD.  
2  The use of qualified NGOs to assist with and conduct surveying and mapping may be considered.

Appendix 4  13 
6.  Data on Infrastructure and Municipal Services Delivery.  Assess the total financial 
envelope available for the urban development sector, including provincial and local government 
and aid pipelines. Collect and assess community data on general affordability and willingness to 
pay for water supply, sanitation, and solid waste collection and disposal. Describe, map, and 
quantify  the  condition  of  basic  amenities  and  urban  services,  highlighting  needs  and 
deficiencies,  including  the  subsectors  of  water  supply,  sanitation,  sewerage  and  sewage 
treatment,  solid  waste  management,  drainage,  pavements  and  small  roads,  and specific 
reference to existing distribution systems, leakages and waste composition, pressure and water 
frequency,  materials  used,  and  system  adequacy  and  efficiency.  Discuss  managerial  and 
administrative arrangements. Examine the current environmental situation and the severity of 
potential environmental health problems due to lack of access to basic infrastructure. Conduct 
an inventory and critically review all relevant initiatives for infrastructure development, studies, 
plans and programs, and public and private sector proposals. Describe existing relevant O&M 
procedures, tariffs, and status of billing and collection for the selected subsectors.   
 
B.  Project Planning and Design through Consensus with Stakeholders (1–2 months) 
7.   To ensure community participation from planning and design stages and enhanced 
ownership, the consultants will carry out public consultations in each of the selected towns. The 
process will typically include the following: (i) Identify individuals to represent the various 
stakeholder groups from towns and communities. Under the devolution process in Pakistan, 
town/talukas  are  mandated  to  undertake  solid  waste  management  and  water  supply  and 
sanitation design and implementation. Stakeholder selection and consultation will therefore 
ensure their participation. Allow the stakeholders to nominate their own representatives, and 
ensure that all major stakeholder groups are represented; (ii) Develop an issues assessment in 
consultation with all major stakeholder groups in the sector. Identify major sector issues, where 
the various stakeholders disagree, and where they may be able to find common ground. Explore 
issues that affect both the formulation of a project investment, and summarize views in an 
issues matrix. Define the detailed methodology for the consensus building efforts. Circulate the 
draft issues assessment to all participants for comments; make a translation of the final version 
available to all participants, as required; (iii) Coordinate a consensus group that includes all the 
stakeholders  identified.  The  participants,  wherever  possible,  should  be  high-level staff or 
community representatives, capable of making commitments on behalf of their organization. 
The gender balance of the group should also be considered.3 Establish a schedule and reserve 
a venue for a series of consensus meetings, preferably in a neutral location. Prepare the 
agenda  for  each  meeting  to  focus  on  specific  issues,  with  specific  target  outputs.  The 
participants for each thematic session may be varied to focus the discussion, but the outputs of 
each session will be shared with the entire consensus group; (iv) The beginning of each 
meeting should clearly lay out the ground rules for the process, the basis for decision making, 
and the target output. A single text process will be used to document the proceedings. Equal 
opportunity and encouragement will be given for all stakeholders to participate. All attempts will 
be made to reach consensus on every important issue. The consultants will clearly document, 
summarize, and seek agreement on the output of each session. The summary of the output of 
the meeting will be circulated to the entire group soon after each meeting, and comments 
incorporated; (v) Circulate the Issues assessment at least 1 week before the first consensus 
meeting. The issues to be discussed and resolved through the consensus meetings will include 
(a) realistic basic urban services subcomponents; (b) the institutional mechanisms most suitable 
for delivery schemes, clearly defining roles of each stakeholder; (c) a strategy for effectively 
mobilizing communities, with specific focus on involving women; (d) optimal strategy for O&M, 
                                                 
3  Women’s participation will be sought through NGO coordination and female counselor representations.

14  Appendix 4 
addressing institutional and financial sustainability issues, as well as the need for major repairs; 
and (f) sustainable mechanisms for monitoring and evaluation. Explore interest, response, and 
willingness to implement component-sharing and cost-sharing concepts, as developed under 
other schemes such as Orangi in Karachi. Other factors may also be considered, based on the 
discussions of the group. In developing the solutions, the consultant/facilitator may use problem 
trees, logical frameworks, or other similar project design tools, to guide and focus the process. 
 
C.  Detailed Feasibility Study (4–5 months) 
8.  Project Design. For selected low-income community areas and criteria developed under 
phase  II,  prepare  a  preliminary  engineering  design;  and  undertake  detailed  subproject 
preparation  activities,  including  suitable  technical  options  acceptable  to  communities.  The 
consultants will (i) complete the technical design for least-cost water supply and sanitation, 
public toilets, sewerage, wastewater treatment, solid waste management, drainage, and access 
options selected in consultation with the community; (ii)  conduct a complementary physical 
assessment of underground water supplies, including modeling of water-table replenishment, 
water  quality  analysis4  of  groundwater  and/or  surface  water  resources  for  each  town,  an 
assessment of surface water resources suitable for water extraction (including flow fluctuations 
throughout the year and existing uses upstream and downstream) and evaluate integrated 
water resources management options for each town; (iii) discuss the technical viability of the 
various proposed options for each project subcomponent, and demonstrate that they are the 
least cost-option under a combined system approach; (iv) assess the impact of wastewater 
collection and treatment on water quality of receiving watercourses prior to and after project 
construction; (v) assess the adequacy of wastewater treatment and solid waste management 
facilities to accommodate incremental amounts; (vi) develop the outline strategy for proposed 
hygiene education, and water and environmental monitoring systems; (vii) review O&M options 
and  prepare  optimal  O&M  strategy  for  community  implementation,  including  technical 
procedures to ensure efficiency and long life/sustainability of sewers, waterways, pumping 
stations, solid waste management subcomponents, etc, and proper financial, accounting and 
managerial arrangements for O&M; (viii) review and/or define design criteria and standards, (ix) 
outline  designs,  construction  staging,  implementation,  tendering  and  major  civil  works 
schedules, staffing requirements, selection of appropriate equipment including maintenance and 
inspection of subcomponents; (x) prepare consulting inputs for project implementation; (xi) 
identify the requirements for key advance actions to avoid delay in implementation; (xii) in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  requirements  for  the  project  performance  management  systems, 
develop  project  monitoring  and  evaluation  arrangements  for  executing  and  implementing 
agencies,  including  the  content  and  format  of  progress  reports,  and  discuss  with  all 
stakeholders, ensuring that monitoring and evaluation is also undertaken by the beneficiaries. In 
consultation with stakeholders, develop a logical framework outlining goal, purpose, outputs, 
and activities with clear links to targets and indicators to monitor project development impact 
and overall performance. 
 
9.  Project  Costs,  Financial  and  Economic  Analyses.  The  consultants  will  use  the 
COSTAB program to (i) estimate project costs; (ii) summarize the project costs estimated for 
land, civil works, equipment, materials, resettlement (if any), environmental monitoring and 
mitigation, consulting services, taxes and duties, project management and capacity building, 
and interest and other charges during construction; (iii) compile and present procurement 
contract packages, clearly indicating the packages to be financed by the ADB loan in line with 
the Guidelines for Procurement under Asian Development Bank Loans and (iv) prepare detailed 
                                                 
4  Close coordination with Sindh EPA and UNICEF will be established to optimize water quality testing.

Appendix 4  15 
financing and disbursement plans. The consultants will conduct Project economic and financial 
analyses  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects, 
Guidelines  for  Economic  Analysis  of  Water  Supply  Projects,  Guidelines for the Financial 
Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development 
Bank, Economic Analysis in 2002: a Retrospective, and Economic Analysis Retrospective 2003 
Update. The consultants will (i) describe the macroeconomic and sector context, (ii) update 
water demand, wastewater discharge, and solid waste generation and disposal levels, as well 
as projections for various end user groups (e.g. irrigation water re-use); (iii) assess project 
alternatives and confirm the least-cost solution; (iv) review cost recovery policies, and tariff 
levels in each town; (v) propose cost recovery mechanisms (including necessary institutional 
arrangements) through taxes, user charges and/or other techniques for O&M and recovery of 
initial investments, and tariff structure for each subproject for short and medium term, taking into 
account affordability, willingness to pay, water conservancy, cross-subsidization, and full cost 
recovery  requirements;5  (vi)  estimate  the  detailed  economic  project  cost  for  the  selected 
alternative  applying  appropriate  disaggregation  of  costs,  standard  conversion  factors,  and 
shadow prices as required; (vii) identify all quantifiable and unquantifiable project economic 
benefits  considering  with  a  without  scenario,  as  well  as  incremental  and  nonincremental 
benefits; (viii) review the financial performance of selected municipalities; (ix) prepare financial 
projections for operations 10 years after project completion; (x) compute relevant financial 
indicators for each town to assess financial viability; (xi) assess the financial viability of the 
project; (xii) estimate economic and financial internal  rates of return and perform sensitivity 
analyses, including switching values and calculation of real weighted average cost of capital, 
(xiii) calculate the poverty impact ratio and conduct a distribution analysis.  
 
10.  Capacity Building and Institutional Strengthening. To ensure the sustainability of the 
investments under the Project, the consultants will develop a carefully designed capacity-
building program for all participating urban local bodies, especially in collecting, updating, 
organizing, and managing financial information for routine work of the municipality. The potential 
for provincial intercity water supply and sanitation know-how sharing and networking programs 
will be explored. In addition, the consultants will devise a comprehensive capacity-building 
program for communities to manage, operate, and maintain proposed facilities, including, where 
relevant, user charges community-collection and administration. Capacity-building activities will 
also address environmental and hygiene education and awareness programs and campaigns.6  
 
11.  Environmental  Assessment.  The  consultants  will  prepare  an  initial  environmental 
examination and summary or environmental impact analysis and summary covering all towns 
and subcomponents, and for the whole Project in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy 
and ADB’s Environmental Guidelines (2003), as well as Pakistan environmental protection 
agency regulations. Assess (i) positive and negative environmental impacts of proposed urban 
social infrastructure and services related to location, design, construction, and O&M; (ii) propose 
mitigation measures and develop a full environmental monitoring plan; (iii) conduct consultations 
as  per  ADB  requirements,  and  (iv)  formulate  environmental  management  plans  for 
environmental sensitive subcomponents. The consultants will prepare a sample/pilot Agenda 21 
sustainable development strategy for a selected urban center.7  
                                                 
5  The  consultants  will  be  informed  by  the  tariff  methodology  study  developed  under  Capacity  Building  for 
Environmental Management in Sindh TA (ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for 
Capacity Building for Environmental Management. Manila) and ADB’s Economics Research Department  Technical 
Notes 9 and 10. 
6  Initiatives, such as those supported to date by United Nations Children’s Fund will be studied. In addition, the 
consultants will evaluate similar thematic initiatives undertaken by NGOs in the area. 
7  City selection criteria will include expressions of interest, commitment, and extent of environmental degradation.

16  Appendix 4 
12.  Social and Resettlement Assessment. The consultants will (i) assess the Project’s 
social impact, including  patterns of water use, water costs, perception of the environment, 
income  levels,  and  distribution,  in  accordance  with  Guidelines  for  Incorporation  of  Social 
Dimensions in ADB Operations; (ii) ascertain the number of indigenous people and minorities 
and their socioeconomic status and specific anticipated project impact on them, using among 
others, the checklist Categorization of Indigenous People and, if necessary, develop indigenous 
people development plans according to ADB’s Policy on Indigenous People; and (iii) based on 
ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development and assisted by ADB’s Gender Checklist for Water 
Supply and Sanitation  and Gender Checklist on Urban Development Projects, assess local 
gender-related constraints and opportunities for development and formulate a gender action 
plan for the ensuing Project. 
 
13.  The consultants will at an early stage of TA implementation, apply ADB’s resettlement 
checklists to identify resettlement issues and ascertain the nature and degree of the Project’s 
impacts on  affected households. Based on the assessment, the consultants will determine 
whether resettlement impacts are significant and if this is the case, prepare, in accordance with 
ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and Handbook on Resettlement, a resettlement plan 
based on subproject design in each town, including (i) a review and assessment of key national 
policies, laws, and guidelines regarding land acquisition (specifically regarding unauthorized 
settlements), and compensation; (ii) identify and enumerate people likely to be affected through 
a survey/census and asset inventory that identifies all types of loss; (iii) through consultation 
with potentially affected people, ascertain preferential relocation areas, compensation, and 
livelihood restoration; (iv) establish an entitlement cutoff date and estimate the requirements for 
financial resources, comparing with resources made available within the country; (iv) provide 
options for relocating housing and other structures, including transfer to established new sites 
and options for livelihood restoration and mechanisms for addressing grievances; (v) define 
institutional responsibilities for approving, implementing, managing, financing, and monitoring 
the resettlement plan, implementation schedules, capacity building, financial plan and budgets, 
and plan for internal and external monitoring and evaluation of the resettlement plan.  
 
14.  The consultants will (i) develop a participatory framework for community participation in 
the identification, planning, and design of the Project; (ii) engage mobilizers from phase I of the  
TA, providing training to equip them for carrying out activities in phase II to be continued when 
the Project is actually in place; (iii) develop the participatory framework into a manual to guide 
social mobilizers in a step-by-step approach to conduct activities in phase II, and be used during 
the training for social mobilizers; (iv) prepare a strategy for community mobilization/community 
organization  strategy  for  implementation  under  the  resulting  Project;  reviewing  previous 
approaches to community organization for urban and environmental management in Sindh and 
Pakistan, refine a preferred approach in consultation with other international agencies and 
NGOs, and detail project activities to organize communities for O&M of water utilities and solid 
waste collection and disposal; and (v) assess the required needs and the distribution and 
capabilities of local NGOs in selected subsectors and towns.  
 
15.  Implementation  Assistance.  The  consultants  will  estimate  project  requirements  to 
improve skills in engineering, planning, project management, and other essential disciplines. 
Based on evaluation of staff and available skills, recommend additional recruitment/upgrading of 
expertise. Assess the institutional strengths and weaknesses of executing and implementing 
agencies;  and  recommend  strengthening  of  institutional  capabilities  through  organizational 
changes, implementation arrangements, staff training and use of consultants.
